questions.question: The man complained that he ………………………….
questions.description: When the main verb is in the past tense, we need a past tense in the subordinate clause as well.

questions.question: She asked me if she ………………………….. use my laptop.
questions.description: Could is the past tense of can. When the main verb is in the past tense, we need a past tense in the subordinate clause as well.

questions.question: I want to know why you ………………………. to me.
questions.description: Use do with you. In the simple present tense, we make questions and negatives with do and does.

questions.question: I waited for hours but she …………………………….
If you ………………………. a little faster, you could overtake her.
questions.description: In type 2 conditional, we use a simple past in the if-clause and would/could / might + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: It is time you …………………………… blaming others for your failures.
questions.description: After it is time, a past tense is used with a present or future meaning.

questions.question: What will you do if you …………………………….. that job?
questions.description: In type 1 conditional, we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will / can / may + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: By next September, I …………………………… in this college for twenty years.
questions.description: We use the future perfect to say that an activity will have completed by a certain point of time in future.

questions.question: I asked her what she …………………………. there.
We ………………………….. the job by next Monday.
He ………………………….. ill for two months, before he died.
questions.description: Perfect tenses are more common with the time expressions for and since. We use the past perfect to talk about the earlier of two past events.
